entry.title: Conclusion and links
entry.content:
Conclusion

Artificial gravity will be difficult to accomplish, though it will also be essential to space travel. If we were to move around in a spinning space station, we would feel unexpected “forces” acting on us. An artificial gravity habitat could be built in the near future with the right designs in place. For now, the Coriolis effect gives us something to think about. Now we know how it would work.

Links

My experience building the model

The math behind this model

The Python code

I wrote to generate the graph in ‘How does the Coriolis effect work?’


Another Coriolis model

This website contains another interesting Coriolis model. Here, Andy Giger poses a similar question: what does it look like if you have spinning water jets? As you can see in his model, the water veers forward, into the direction of rotation. If you look carefully, you will see that every dot individually follows a perfectly straight line.

Try it!

My experience with physics

I would quickly like to note my experience with physics. I do not have a physics degree, but I have studied physics-mechanics three times in school. I was successful each time. Physics fascinates me!

I originally studied physics as a high school student. The next year, I studied physics again as an advanced placement student.

In college, I ended up taking this course a third time due to some school requirements. I took “Principles of Physics I, for Scientists and Engineers.” I earned an A.

In none of these classes was the Coriolis effect ever mentioned. I was never given a physics problem similar to this one. It seems too complicated for an exam. I cannot remember where I originally read about the Coriolis effect. This subject is something that has fascinated me for years.

entry.title: How does the Coriolis effect work?

link.title: How does the Coriolis effect work?

entry.content:
How does the Coriolis effect work?

The Coriolis effect causes objects in a rotating environment to move where you do not expect them to. To understand why you must take a look at the movement from a perspective that is not rotating.

If you were to jump in artificial gravity, the centripetal force at your feet would cease the instant you leave the floor. You would observe Coriolis “forces” as you “accelerate” back to the floor; however, an onlooker who is not spinning would see you move in a straight line.

Now we will return to the coin toss. The graphic above shows what a vertical coin toss looks like to an observer outside the station. The coin cuts through the middle by going in a straight line; the thrower continues moving with the floor, taking the longer path.

The Coriolis force is different based on the direction an object is moving. This is what you would see:

  • Objects moving with the rotation would feel an extra downward “force.” They are effectively rotating more quickly.

  • Objects moving opposite the rotation would become “lighter” or would move “up.” If you matched the station’s speed, you would become weightless.

  • Objects moving “upward” would be pushed into the rotation.

  • Objects moving “downward” would be pushed opposite the rotation.

The larger the station, the smaller these Coriolis effects become; however, to make the effects unnoticeable, you would need an impractically massive space station! I have modeled our coin toss in a logarithmic graph. Earth-“normalness” improves incredibly slowly, on a logarithmic scale.

This assumes the throw starts from four feet and goes to a total height of seven feet.

entry.title: Artificial gravity in science fiction
entry.content:
Artificial gravity in science fiction

Artificial gravity has never been used in space, so our current perspective comes from science fiction. Sci-fi movies are not realistic; a “real” picture is not cinematic and would be difficult to simulate. No space movie has ever depicted the Coriolis effect.

In many sci-fi movies, you see an artificial gravity “generator” underneath the station that uses an energy source to produce pure gravity. This is impossible!

Some movies have taken a more “realistic” approach to sci-fi, showing rotating space stations. I will discuss some of these stories below. There are many options to choose from.

Sci-fi films with rotating spacecraft

Here is a short list of sci-fi films with rotating spacecraft, and the names of those spacecraft:

  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968): Spacecraft Discovery One

  • Ender’s Game (2013): Battle School

  • Interstellar (2014): Endurance

  • The Martian (2015): Hermes

  • Passengers (2016): the Avalon

Even in films that take a more realistic approach, there are some mistakes in their gravity simulations. Here are a few examples.

The Avalon

In Passengers, the entire story takes place aboard a rotating spacecraft, the Avalon. Passengers travel for many years to emigrate to another star system. In this movie, you see correctly that a ride on the elevator could temporarily cause 0g. One mistake is that a failure in the gravity drive would not cause gravity to “stop” abruptly; the station’s rotational momentum would prevent that.

Try it!

Diameter=500 m

Start height=4 m

Angle=0°

Speed=0 m/s

Gravity=100%

This button shows you how the waterfall in the main concourse of the Avalon should appear.

Ender’s Game is a fantasy story, but the main plot is about artificial gravity and weightlessness. Ender is trained to fight weightless space battles in a zero-g “battle room.” In this “battle room,” every action Ender takes depends on his direction. This would also be true in artificial gravity due to the Coriolis effect. One missing gravity detail is that the hallway into the battle room would be almost zero-g. Gravity would vary based on how far you are from the center of rotation.

Try it!

Diameter=2640 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=90°

Speed=20 ft/s

Gravity=100%

In battle school, if Ender were to toss an object 10 feet away in his room, it would land about 1½ feet off-target (assuming a half-mile diameter).

It seems clear that an accurate spacecraft story requires a physics expert. We simply do not have experience with such things to know clearly what it would be like.

entry.title: The math behind this model
entry.content:
The math behind this model

The math I employed in my Coriolis article is thorny and involved, yet this model still follows the rules of basic physics and kinematics. So we have a physics problem to solve! To review, we want to find where a coin toss would land on a virtual space station. This is the most important part of the model’s math.

Set-up the coordinate system

To fully understand what happens during our coin toss, we must use a perspective that is not rotating. The Coriolis effect is not a real force, but is simply described by the difference between rotation and real gravity.

In physics, we must set our coordinate system before we solve our math problem. The station is a virtual coordinate system with (0,0) at its exact center. I assumed that the station is rotating clockwise. The math might have been slightly simpler if I had chosen counterclockwise instead, but this is how I imagined it. For our convenience, the moment of the throw takes place at the instant the person is standing at the bottom of the curve. The person throws the coin with the force that would have been needed to get it 3 feet up in the air on Earth.

While we are still holding the coin, we (and the coin) have a leftwards velocity due to the clockwise rotation. The centripetal force is pushing us upwards, directly towards the middle of the station.

At the moment the coin is released, it will no longer have any forces acting on it. The coin is no longer touching the station. It will continue to have the same leftwards horizontal velocity, but it will now have a vertical velocity component defined by how hard you would have thrown it on earth.

Now that I have set up the physics, I will explain the order of operations for our quest. In my advanced physics classes, the professors emphasized creating an equation that can solve your problem for you. This problem is far too complex to be placed into one equation; thus, we will solve it in steps, and the computer will give us the answer.

We want to find how far away a coin would unexpectedly land from the thrower’s feet. To find this, we need to find out the coordinates of where both the thrower and the coin would end up. First, we need the velocity of the coin when it launches. Using this, we can solve for its landing coordinate and the time it elapsed in the air. We can then use the time elapsed in the air to find where the thrower would end up in an equivalent time period. We can use this to find the separation between the coin and the thrower’s feet.

To review, here are the steps to solving our math problem:

  1. Solve for the coin's starting velocity
    • Both horizontal and vertical components
  2. Find the coin's landing coordinates
  3. Get the time elapsed
  4. Calculate the arc swept by the thrower
    • Use this to get the final coordinates
  5. Use the coordinates to calculate the distance between the coin and the thrower's feet


Starting Velocity
Vertical Component

The throw velocity is based on how hard the coin would have been thrown on Earth. This is basic kinematics, and once again, this part of the problem takes place on Earth.

Physics tells us, that at the top of an arc of motion on Earth, the velocity will equal zero as the object changes direction. The coin will land directly under where it was thrown.

This is the relevant kinematics fomula:

Variables:

  • $v_f$ is the final velocity
  • $v_0$ is the initial velocty
  • $a$ is the acceleration
  • $x$ is the distance traveled upwards

In our formula:

  • $v_0$ is the initial velocity, the variable we want
  • $v_f=0$ (the top of our throwing arc)
  • $x$ is the height of our throw (3 feet up)
  • $a=-g_e=-32.174$ ft/s/s, the gravity on earth.


By solving, we get:


This is the vertical component of the coin’s starting velocity.

Horizontal Component

Before we solve for the coin’s initial horizontal velocity, please note that the coin does not feel the same force of gravity as you do on the floor of the station. It has a smaller radius to the center of the station because you are holding it in your hand. Thus, the coin’s horizontal velocity would not be quite the same as if it were touching the floor.

The floor’s “gravity” is a constant acceleration toward the center. This is the equation for rotational acceleraton:

Variables:

  • $v_t$ is the horizontal velocity of an object on the station
  • r is the radius where the object is located
  • a is the acceleration felt by the object
  • $\omega$ is the rotational rate of the station in radians/second.

$\omega$ would be the same at the floor and at the coin. We can calculate $\omega$ using values at the floor (1g acceleration), and then use $\omega$ to find the horizontal velocity of the coin.

In our formula:

  • $a=-32.174$ ft/s/s, the acceleration at the floor
  • $r$ is the radius of the station.

We can then use $\omega$ to calculate the horizontal velocity of the coin. Using the formula at the top, we get:

The model’s starting height is how far above the floor the coin is tossed from. The coin’s radius would be the total radius minus the coin’s starting height.

The velocity is set to be negative, because the coin is going left in our coordinate plane. Left is a negative direction.

Thus, our final formula:

Our variables:

  • a = the acceleration of the station, -32.174 ft/s/s
  • $r_{s}$=the radius of the station
  • $h_{person}$=the height of the person


The Coin’s Landing Coordinates

We can use the velocity components of the coin to find its landing coordinates. The coin is traveling up and to the left in a straight line; the slope of the path it follows is the fraction of the two velocity components, $\frac{v_y}{v_x}$.

The equation for a line: $y = mx + b$

Our variables:

  • $m=\frac {rise}{run}=\frac{v_y}{v_x}$, it will be negative.
  • $b=$ the y-intercept $=-(r_{s}-h_{c})$

My computer tells me that $v_x=-23.82329$ ft/s, and $v_y=13.80403$ ft/s. This is the formula for the path of the coin:

Now, we need to find where this line intersects with a circle. Here is the formula for a circle:

We can cheat and solve this using an online graphing website:

In this image, you can see the path of the coin and its final intersection with the ground, up and to the left. The coin starts at the y-intercept.

Now, we will solve this by hand. For our computer model, we need formulas that the computer can solve!

Rearrange and simplify to a quadratic equation (format $0=ax^2+bx+c$):

The quadratic formula:

Plug in our variables and simplify (I skipped a few steps for brevity):

This is our formula for the x-coordinate of the coin. The correct value will be the answer that is negative, because the coin goes to the left. The equation correctly gives us -23.967 when we solve with the (-) operator.

Now we need to solve for the y-component that matches this x-component:

This gives us 7.113. There is one problem: solving this way only gives us the absolute value of the y-component!

To get the correct sign of the y-component, we need to use the quadratic formula again.

Rearrange and simplify to a quadratic equation:

Put into the quadratic formula and simplify:

We already know the absolute value of the y-component. The quadratic formula tells us that this number should be negative, -7.113. We arrived at this number using the (+) operator.

Our final coordinates are (-23.967, -7.113). This matches the values from the graphing website.

The correct operators in the quadratic formula were (-) when solving for x, and (+) when solving for y. This is fairly intuitive, because the coin moves up and to the left (negative x direction, positive y direction).

These operators differ if the coin moves in a direction other than up and to the left (e.g. if it is thrown in a direction other than straight up). Fortunately, the operators are intuitive based on which direction the coin moves.

Thus, our final formulas are:

Our variables:

  • $m=\frac {v_y}{v_x}$. $v_x$ is negative because the coin is moving left.
  • $r_{c}$ is the radius at the coin.
  • $r_{s}$ is the radius of the station.



Time Elapsed in the Air

Now that we have the landing coordinates, we can solve for the exact time elapsed using kinematics equations. First, we need the distance traveled. We will calculate this using the Pythagorean Theorem. The final coordinates of the coin are (x_f, y_f), and the initial coordinates are (0,$-r_{c}$).

Pythagorean theorem: $d=\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$.

Using our variables: $d=\sqrt{x_f^2+(y_f+r_{c})^2}$

We also need to solve for the velocity. We have the x and y components. The velocity, with the Pythagorean theorem, is $v=\sqrt {v_x^2 + v_y^2}$.

We know from basic kinematics that $d=vt$ for objects that are not accelerating. We can rearrange this and plug in our values. We get:

Our variables:

  • $x_f$ = the final x-coordinate of the coin
  • $y_f$ = the final y-coordinate of the coin
  • $v_x$ = the velocity x-component
  • $v_y$ = the velocity y-component
  • $r_{c}$ = the radius at the coin, before it is launched


The Arc Swept By the Person

We can use the time variable to calculate the angle a person will cover while the coin is in the air. This will give us the final coordinates of the person.

We have already calculated the station’s rotation rate in the beginning of our problem. This is $\omega$, in radians/second.

The person starts at an angle of $\frac{3\pi}{2}$ (270 degrees). The person is sweeping a negative arc, because they are traveling clockwise (counterclockwise is positive for angles).

If $\theta_t$ is the total arc swept by the person, then you would expect $\theta_t=\theta_f-\theta_0$. However, you must keep in mind the negative direction of the arc being traveled. We can switch the sign by flipping the terms of the equation. Thus, our formula is $\theta_t=\theta_0-\theta_f$, where $\theta_0=\frac{3\pi}{2}$. Now rearrange the terms:

With rotational kinematics, we can calculate the arc swept by the person:

Put the equations together:

We have just calculated the person’s final angle in the station. Now, we have a set of polar coordinates: we have the final angle and the radius. We can convert these polar coordinates to cartesian coordinates using the equations:

Our final x and y coordinates:

Our variables:

  • r = the radius of the station
  • $\omega$ = the rotational rate of the station (calculated when we found the horizontal velocity)
  • t = the time elapsed while the coin is in the air


The Final Answer

Now that we have the landing coordinates of the coin, and the person’s final coordinates, we can calculate the straight line distance between the two using the Pythagorean theorem. This formula gives us our answer:

Javascript calculates to a precision of about 15 decimal points. This is insufficient for some calculations; thus my code uses the Decimal.js package to support 30 decimal places instead. The model breaks up the path of the coin into 100 pieces and moves real-time between them to make a realistic arc on the screen.


Max Height Achieved

My table also displays the max height achieved by the coin. Unfortunately, there is no formula to calculate this. I generated this number by creating a maximization script; the script sweeps up and down the path of the coin to find the point that is at the farthest distance from the circle.

entry.title: The history of artificial gravity research

link.title: The history of artificial gravity research

entry.content:
The history of artificial gravity research

Organizations like NASA and SpaceX have been working feverishly to try to make life in space viable. Space agencies will eventually need to construct artificial gravity habitats to solve the health problems of weightlesness. Unfortunately, no space agency has active plans to build an artificial-gravity habitat, though NASA’s archives are littered with proposals for one.

Here are some of the things the world’s space agencies have accomplished:

  • The Gemini 8 mission (March 1966) accidentally produced 4 g’s after a thruster incorrectly fired. The fast rotation caused intense nausea, and the astronauts nearly blacked out from the g-forces. The mission was aborted.
Gemini 11
  • The Gemini 11 mission (September 1966) purposely rotated two capsules connected by a 36-meter tether to produce 0.0005 g. The astronauts did not feel the gravitational force (the perception threshold is about 0.2 g), but they observed objects slowly floating toward the floor of their capsule. They reported it had been “an interesting and puzzling experience.”
Try it!

Diameter=45 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=0 m/s

Gravity=.05%

Press this green button to emulate the gravity of the Gemini 11 mission. It takes 23 seconds for a dropped coin to land.

  • By 1973, NASA had not recognized the need for artificial gravity. At this point, NASA’s only concern with zero gravity was motion sickness, which was only a problem for the first few days in orbit. This was the NASA flight surgeon’s position: “The magnitude of the motion-sickness problem experienced by astronauts to date does not appear to suggest clearly the need for design and incorporation of artificial gravity system in near-future space vehicles.”
Kosmos 782

  • The Russians, however, were interested in artificial gravity. The Soviet space program initially believed that a human could not survive more than 14 days in space; the Soviets believed that the heart and blood vessels would be unable to adapt to weightlessness.

  • In 1975, on Kosmos 782, the Soviets centrifuged animals in space. Fish and turtles were centrifuged at 1 g for 20-days in a 75 cm diameter centrifuge. The researchers did not find any differences between either the centrifuged animals, animals housed in 0g, or Earth-bound animals.

Skylab
  • The (American) Skylab crews took advantage of the large open compartment to run around the curved circumference. Running in a circle created gravity. They reported no difficulty with either locomotion or motion sickness.
  • The negative effects of weightlessness became clear during long-duration missions on Russian space stations such as Mir.
Off-axis rotator

  • In 1998, the European Space Agency built an “off-axis rotator” for the ISS. This device centrifuged humans for seven minutes at a time at several speeds. Subjects said they felt like they were standing on their heads.

  • Several studies on Earth have looked at long-term bed rest, which produces similar health effects to zero gravity. A 1998 study in Tokyo found that one hour a day in a centrifuge prevents blood volume from dropping in a bed rester and maintains the blood-pressure reflex. In 2005, NASA conducted similar studies in their Short-Radius Centrifuge in Houston.

  • In December 2014, NASA launched a fruit-fly centrifuge to study the effects of artificial gravity on the immune system.

The scientific community periodically comes up with new gravity ideas, though we will never fully understand life in artificial gravity until we create an environment for outer space.

Rotation and nausea

Living in a centrifuge may be nauseating. Minimizing the rotation rate would reduce this nausea. We can reduce the revolutions per minute (rpm) by increasing the station size; however, it is unclear what rotation rate would be desirable, and large stations would be expensive. When we finally build a space station with simulated gravity, we should experiment with several rotation rates.

Are you dizzy yet?

Unlike astronauts in zero gravity, rotating astronauts must adapt to more than one sensation. While rotating, each direction of motion produces a different effect on the inner ear. This means that individuals would need to adjust to the rotation itself and to sudden changes in direction. Furthermore, windows could be disorienting on a rotating space station.

Nausea research on Earth began in 1958 in the Slow Rotating Room, a facility in Pensacola, Florida. NASA placed individuals in a slowly rotating room for several days.

NASA's Slow Rotating Room

The Slow Rotating Room generated some important findings. Study participants quickly learned to restrict their head movements, otherwise they would feel sharp nausea reactions (“acute nausea”). Over time, these individuals adjusted and became less restricted.

This page explains: “Although few adverse effects are present when rotation rate is less than 1 rpm, higher rates produce motion sickness (similar to that occurring during the acute period of adaptation to weightlessness).” Researchers found that their test subjects could adapt to 3 rpm.

Try it!

Diameter=200 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=4 m/s

Gravity=100%

A station would need to be 200 meters to produce 3 rpm at full gravity. The International Space Station is 109 meters wide by comparison. Press this button to see the coin toss emulated on a 200-meter space station (the coin lands 20 cm away).

Higher rotation rates would be more difficult to adapt to. In 10 rpm, individuals showed no adaptation after 12 days. The study indicated it is possible to build up to this rate in small increments, about 1-2 rpm per day; this might be an impractically long adjustment. My model’s default settings display a station at about 11 rpm (the speed for 1g with a diameter of 50 feet).

It is unclear how significant these studies are. Unlike these studies, living in space would rotate you vertically, not horizontally.

A 1993 study in Udine, Italy focused on vertical rotation in a bicycle-powered centrifuge. Participants were able to move their heads without acute motion sickness at rates up to 19-21 rpm. Unlike the Slow Rotating Room, this study did not expose participants over several days; this would be very difficult.

It is not clear how well our bodies would adapt to rotation in space.

Construction ideas

There are a few strategies that could be helpful for building a rotating space station.

Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=33%

  • We could build a space station that produces less than 1g. This would not need to rotate as quickly, and it might produce some positive health benefits.
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=200%

  • Studies have indicated that intermittent gravity is helpful. Would a higher rotation rate be tolerable if it is only for an hour a day? Try the coin toss in 2g!

  • As we saw in Gemini 11, it is possible to simulate gravity by rotating two capsules connected by a tether. This may prove less expensive than building an enormous station.

  • A modular station could be expanded over time, allowing us to reduce the rpm requirements or increase the gravity capability. Gravity would be highest at the ends and lowest in the middle.

  • A station’s rotation rate would require small adjustments over time. Spinning a reaction wheel could manage it without thrusters. Otherwise, the station would need to use propellant, which would be used up over time. This reaction wheel would spin in the opposite direction of the station and could be electrically powered. This wheel would need to be frictionless.

Actual Spacecraft Proposals

  • In 2011, NASA proposed the rotating Nautilus-X as a possible stopover for astronauts embarking on long-distance missions; it would be relatively inexpensive and feasible (~$3bn). It seems likely that we will build something similar to this first.
Nautilus-X (proposed)
  • This next image is for the Rotating Mars spacecraft, a 1989 concept idea. A space station using this tethered method could have an arbitrarily large diameter. A large space station at 1g may require exceptionally strong tethers using future materials such as carbon nanotubes.
1989
  • The 1969 design below requires a few revisions to work. The center corridor would need to be an elevator or a ladder. Also, you would be unable to stand in the long cylindrical containers; they are oriented in the wrong direction. This would work if we used many small modules in a chain.
1969
  • In 1975, NASA designed a massive theoretical ring station, a “Stanford torus,” as a thought experiment. The Stanford torus has a proposed diameter of 1800 meters (1.1 miles), the minimum size to produce 1 rpm with full gravity. Here is an interesting news story about it.
The Stanford torus
Try it!

Diameter=1800 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=4 m/s

Gravity=100%

Press this button to see the coin toss emulated on the Stanford Torus. The coin toss lands 8 cm (3 in) away. Perhaps someday we will reach out to the stars with a station like this one.

Much of the information on this page has been drawn from this link.

entry.title: Health effects of weightlessness
entry.content:
Health effects of weightlessness

Weightlessness is not a problem for short space flights; however, on long-duration flights it would be debilitating. Missions to Mars or beyond will present serious dangers without gravity.

It was initially believed that the effects of weightlessness could be counteracted through exercise. It has become clear that it is impossible for astronauts to get sufficient exercise in space to protect them. Nonetheless, several hours of daily exercise is still important to astronauts living in zero gravity.

Astronaut Scott Kelly just completed an important mission on the International Space Station: he stayed in space for an entire year while his identical twin brother lived on earth. This allowed scientists to compare the changes that occurred in Scott’s body to his brother’s, so NASA can better prepare for a mission to Mars. Scientists were able to more thoroughly study the effects of zero gravity on Kelly’s body.

Scott Kelly

Scott Kelly recently wrote a book about his journeys in space. In his book, he describes some of the health effects he experienced from living in space.

In the prologue of his book, Kelly describes what it was like returning to Earth after his year in space. He could hardly stand! He writes, “All of my joints and all of my muscles are protesting the crushing pressure against gravity” (page 6). His blood pooled in his legs, causing swelling and pain, and causing low blood pressure everywhere else. His ankles were so swollen he could not find his ankle bones. His skin became hot, and he developed a strange, massive rash over his body. Doctors do not have experience with humans returning from long-duration space missions.

Throughout the book, Kelly writes some additional medical findings:

  • Immediately after landing, he is surprised by how dizzy he feels. He writes, “When I tried to unstrap myself from my seat and get up, I found I nearly couldn’t move. I felt like I weighed a thousand pounds” (page 230).

  • Some astronauts suffer vision damage during long space missions (page 140); this may be due to increased pressure in the head. This lowers drainage of cerebrospinal fluid, which causes increased pressure on the eyes. These vision changes are permament for some astronauts and temporary for others. Kelly writes that he experienced swelling of the optic nerve and permanent choroidal folds behind the retina.

  • If astronauts do not exercise for several hours each day, they will lose 1 percent of bone mass each month. It is believed that astronauts have permanent structural changes in the bone. If astronauts skip a single exercise session, they feel their muscles atrophy (page 334). If an astronaut were to be injured and unable to exercise, he or she would lose bone mass.

  • Kelly writes that “more than two-thirds of space travelers suffer from some degree of space motion sickness, sometimes debilitating, and there isn’t much to be done but wait it out.” Motion-sick astronauts are as clumsy and tentative “as babies just learning to walk” until this is resolved. It can take astronauts four to six weeks to recover. (Artificial gravity might also cause motion sickness; it is unclear how this would compare.)

Despite this short list of medical greviances, Kelly was nonetheless enthusiastic about his mission. Immediately after landing, he felt confident he could have walked away from the landing site.

Many of the negative effects of zero-gravity have been clear since the Soviets launched Mir; they discovered toxic effects on the bone, muscle, and cardiovascular system.

This paper explains that zero gravity causes “debilitating and potentially fatal problems” including “bone loss, cardiovascular deconditioning, muscle weakening, sensorimotor and neurovestibular disturbances, and regulatory disorders.” Living in zero gravity causes blood to flow to the head, prompting dramatic fluid loss and increased blood thickness. After returning to Earth, thick blood flows back to the lower body, causing the heart rate to increase and blood pressure to drop. Today, returning astronauts also risk bone fractures and muscle tears during their recovery period. The paper says, “Were astronauts to embark upon a journey to Mars today, the 6-month exposure to weightlessness en route would leave them considerably debilitated.” We do not know how the low Martian gravity would affect them after arrival.

If the world intends to send astronauts on long-distance missions, then artificial gravity will be important!

entry.title: Fun things to do with the model

entry.content:
Fun things to do with the computer model

Here are some things you can do with the model.

Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=0 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Try dropping the coin instead of throwing it (throw it at 0 ft/s). It curves in the opposite direction.

  • Next, try dropping the coin from almost the center of the station. With the diameter at 50 feet, place the starting height at 24.5 feet. Imagine you are standing on a tall pole and drop the coin while rotating near the center. It appears to spiral outward slowly due to the low gravity near the center. The coin actually travels in a straight path, but the floor–where we are observing from–rotates relative to the coin.

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
What is this model?

This model demonstrates how much artificial gravity would alter the environment around you on a space station. My model shows that, thanks to the Coriolis effect, artificial gravity would be very strange; it would not look like Earth’s gravity.

You can change the throw to whatever you want by pushing the “Edit Variables” button on the model page. The next page will give you some ideas (“Fun things to do with the computer model”).

What is artificial gravity?

We can simulate gravity by spinning; this is “artificial” gravity. If you swing a bucket of water fast enough around your head, the water will stay inside. This creates what is called the centripetal force.

Unfortunately, we do not currently have a space station that generates gravity, but the physics behind artificial gravity is real and could be put into practice in space.

What is the Coriolis effect?

The Coriolis effect is an effect of artificial gravity that causes objects to move where you do not expect them to. Objects that are rotating do not behave the same as objects that are not. This effect can also be seen in Earth’s weather patterns.

Because of this effect, life in simulated gravity may prove difficult to get used to. The Coriolis effect would affect everything you do. Increasing the size of a space station reduces the Coriolis effect, but eliminating it entirely would require an impossibly large space station.

Model Assumptions

This model assumes:

  • there is no air resistance
  • the numbers in the input menu represent the throw you would have made on Earth
  • before the throw, the coin was rotating with the thrower’s hand

The model shows the thrower’s perspective. The space station’s floor looks stationary to him. He sees outer space rotating counterclockwise.
